title: Habit Tracker — a tiny, offline-first Ionic/Angular app with smart reminders
content: A personal project to learn Angular the practical way: I built a Habit Tracker with a clean dark UI, offline storage, and on-device notifications. Below I walk through what the app does, a few design decisions, and the little engineering bits that made it stable on Android (Capacitor) without needing any backend.
description: ### Core features (what you can do)
- **Create habits** with a name, **period** (Day / Week / Month) and **repetitions per period**.
- **Add reminders** directly when creating a habit or later in Settings: pick a time and select weekdays (defaults to all days if you don’t choose).
- **Edit reminders** at any time; the app cancels old schedules and creates new ones to avoid duplicates.
- **Track progress**: see *current* and *longest streaks* plus a compact streak timeline for each habit.
- **Stay private**: everything is stored locally on your device; there’s no login and no data leaves your phone.
### Screens at a glance
- **Habits list** *(first screenshot)* — compact cards show your progress and streak counters. The floating **+** opens the add dialog.
- **New habit** *(second screenshot)* — choose period & repetitions; tap **Add notification** to attach reminders before saving.
- **Add reminder modal** *(third screenshot)* — a simple time wheel and weekday chips (Mo–Su). If you don’t select days, the reminder runs every day.
- **Settings** *(fourth screenshot)* — per-habit details: current/longest streaks, timeline, quick actions (manage reminders, reset period, delete).
### Tech stack
- **Ionic + Angular (standalone components)** for the UI and routing.
- **Capacitor** for native bridges, especially **Local Notifications** on Android.
- **Offline-first storage** via Capacitor Preferences/Storage; no server required.
- **Dark theme** by default; high-contrast accents for category colors.
### Notifications: what matters on Android 13+
- Android 13+ requires a **runtime permission** for posting notifications. The app asks **only when you add/save reminders**, not on the first launch.
- To keep the app stable, all plugin calls are wrapped in `try/catch`, and scheduling only runs **after** permission is granted.
- Reminders are scheduled per habit and weekday. When you edit reminders, the app **cancels** the old ones first, then **reschedules** the new set.
### Little engineering details
- **Crash-proof plugin usage**: permission checks & scheduling are isolated in a `NotificationService` so UI code stays simple and safe.
- **Deterministic IDs** for reminders (per habit, per time, per day) prevent duplicates.
- **Default-sane UX**: if you add a reminder time but pick no weekdays, the app assumes *every day*.
- **No background surprise**: reminders exist only because you created them; the app doesn’t auto-add or reschedule behind your back.
### What I learned
- Start with a tiny vertical slice (one habit, one reminder), then harden the edges (permissions, cancel/reschedule).
- Capacitor is great for *just-enough native* without leaving the Angular mindset.
- Stability on Android is mostly about **when** you call native APIs and **what happens when they fail** — handle both deliberately.
### Roadmap
- Optional iOS build & minor UI polish for larger screens.
- Export/backup of local data.
- Gentle onboarding & tips for first-time users.
### Try it
The app is currently distributed via Google Play test tracks for quick feedback. If you’re on the tester list, use the opt-in link to install from the Play Store and you’ll get updates automatically.

title: Building My Own Flashcards PWA: A Minimal, Difficulty-Driven Anki Alternative
content: I wanted the spaced repetition feel of Anki but with absolute control over which difficulty levels I review at any given moment. So I built a small, dark-themed flashcards Progressive Web App (PWA) with Angular that runs on my Mac and iPad, works offline, and stores everything locally.

The app is organized around decks, a clean split between edit mode and practice mode, and a 1–10 difficulty scale. After each card, I rate how hard it felt; later, I can start a session that targets exactly one difficulty band—or all cards that are still unsorted.

Under the hood, the app is intentionally simple: a single state service backed by localStorage, JSON export/import for backups and cross-device sync, and a few UI components that keep screenshots front and center so I can study from full-screen code images.
description: ### Goal & Motivation

I really like spaced repetition, but there was one thing that bothered me about Anki: once a card lives in a deck, it's hard to directly control *how often* I see the cards in that deck **by difficulty level**. I wanted something much simpler:
- Plain decks ('stacks') where I store flashcards.
- A 1–10 difficulty rating on each card.
- After each review I manually choose the difficulty.
- When I start a session, I can say: *'Give me only difficulty 7 today'* or *'Only the cards I haven't sorted yet'*.
So I built a small PWA with Angular that focuses exactly on this workflow and nothing else.
### Tech Stack & Architecture
- **Framework:** Angular (standalone components, zoneless app).
- **Deployment:** GitHub Pages, configured as a PWA with `@angular/pwa`.
- **Storage:** `localStorage` in the browser, plus JSON export/import for backups and manual syncing between devices.
- **Platforms:** Runs in the browser, installable on **Mac** and **iPad** as a home-screen app.
- **Styling:** A custom dark theme in SCSS; the whole UI is designed around comfortable long study sessions in low light.
At the heart of the app is one state service:
- `FlashcardsStateService` owns a `FlashcardsState` object.
- This state is serialized 1:1 to `localStorage` under a single key.
- On startup the service loads and **normalizes** state, including a small migration step for older data.
The domain model stays deliberately small:
- `DifficultyLevel` is a union type `1 | 2 | … | 10`.
- `CardSideContent` holds `text` and `imageDataUrls: string[]` so each side can have multiple screenshots.
- `Flashcard` contains `front`, `back`, `difficulty`, and timestamps `createdAt` / `updatedAt`.
- `Deck` is just `id`, `name`, `description?`, and a list of cards.
Because everything is plain JSON, export/import becomes trivial: I simply dump `FlashcardsState` into a file or load it from one.
### Deck Overview: Minimal Home Screen

description.alt: Flashcards app deck overview screen in dark mode

description: The home screen is intentionally sparse:
- A **Backup & restore** card at the top:
- `Export data` downloads a JSON snapshot of every deck and card on this device.
- `Import data` loads a JSON backup and **replaces** the current state after a confirmation dialog.
- A **Create new deck** card with:
- Name field (required).
- Optional description.
- A single 'Create deck' button.
- A list of **Existing decks**:
- Each row shows the deck name and the number of cards.
- Clicking the row opens that deck.
- A `Delete` button lets me remove a deck after confirmation.
This is the page I see both on my Mac and my iPad; it's where I jump into editing or practicing a particular stack.
### Deck Menu: Clean Separation Between Editing and Practice

description.alt: Deck menu with options to edit cards or practice deck

description: When I click a deck, I *don’t* immediately land in a noisy edit UI. Instead I get a **deck menu**:
- A header with deck name and card count.
- Two clear buttons:
- `Edit cards`
- `Practice deck`

This separation sounds small, but it matters: when I'm in practice mode, I want to stay in a focused flow—no text inputs or file pickers on screen. When I'm organizing cards, I don't want to be tempted to start a half-hearted practice session.
### Edit Mode: Text + Multiple Screenshots Per Side

description.alt: Edit deck view with card editor and table of cards

description: Edit mode uses a two-column layout:
1. **Left column – card editor**
- Switches between:
- **Create new card** (empty form).
- **Edit card** (when I click `Edit` on an existing card).
- For both **front** and **back** sides:
- A `Text` textarea.
- An `Images` file input (one screenshot per selection).
- A preview grid that shows all attached images:
- Each image has its own `Remove` button.
- A `Remove all images` button clears the entire list.
- A bottom action row:
- `Add card` / `Save changes`.
- `Cancel` when in editing mode (resets the form).
This is where the **multiple screenshots** feature lives. For algorithm problems I often want:
- the problem statement,
- a reference implementation,
- maybe a diagram—
all glued to the back side of a single card.
2. **Right column – card table**
- A table of all cards in the deck.
- For each card I see:
- Front text (if any).
- Back text (if any).
- A thumbnail of the **first** image on each side.
- A small `+N` badge if there are more images.
- The current difficulty value.
- Each row has `Edit` and `Delete` actions.
This edit view is my workspace for building out big decks, checking that the images look right, and assigning initial difficulties.
### Practice Mode: Difficulty Chips & Full-Screen Screenshots
Practice mode is where the app behaves differently from Anki.
#### Difficulty filter bar

description.alt: Practice mode with colored difficulty filter bar

description: At the top of the practice view there is a horizontal **difficulty bar** made of colored chips:
- `All` (blue/gray blend) – includes every card in the deck.
- `Unsorted` (gray) – only cards that have never been rated (their `updatedAt` equals `createdAt`).
- Colored chips for difficulties **1–10**, laid out like a small rainbow:
- 1: red
- 2: orange
- 3: yellow
- 4: yellow-green
- 5: green
- 6: teal
- 7: cyan
- 8: blue
- 9: indigo
- 10: purple
Each chip shows **two things**:
- The label (`All`, `Unsorted`, or the level number).
- A tiny count underneath (how many cards in the deck currently have that difficulty or are unsorted).
When I tap on a chip, the app doesn’t immediately start anything; it simply remembers my selection. Then I hit:
- `Start practice (N card(s) in deck)` –
- internally, this builds a pool of cards filtered by the selected difficulty and shuffles it.
If there are zero cards for the chosen filter, the app tells me so instead of starting an empty session.
#### The practice card view

description.alt: Practice mode showing the front side of a card
Practice mode showing the back side of a card with code

description: During a session I see:
- A small progress label: `Card i of N`.
- A big card container with:
- Title: `Front side` or `Back side`.
- The corresponding text (or a hint if there is no text).
- Below that, **all images** for the current side:
- Each image stretches up to the width of the card,
- Its height is capped at about 70% of the viewport so it never overflows.
- A `Flip card` button to toggle between front and back.
- Once the back is visible, a rating row:
- Buttons `1` through `10`.
- Clicking one sets `difficulty` and updates `updatedAt`.
- The app then automatically advances to the next card.
When the session ends, practice mode closes and I can either:
- Start a new session with a different difficulty filter, or
- Go back to the deck menu.
### Data Model Details & Migration
Internally, the practice engine is extremely straightforward. Every card has:
- `difficulty: DifficultyLevel` (1–10).
- `createdAt` and `updatedAt` timestamps.
Filtering works like this:
- **All:** use the entire `deck.cards` array.
- **Unsorted:** `updatedAt === createdAt` (i.e. never rated).
- **Specific difficulty k:** `card.difficulty === k`.

The app originally supported only a single image per side (`imageDataUrl`). When I extended it to support **multiple screenshots**, I didn’t want to lose existing data. So the load step includes a small migration:
- If `imageDataUrls` is already an array, use it.
- Else, if there is a single `imageDataUrl`, wrap it as `[imageDataUrl]`.
- Otherwise, the side just has an empty array.
This means even after updating the app, older backups still round-trip cleanly.
### Offline-First: PWA + Manual Sync
Because the app is just static HTML/JS/CSS served from GitHub Pages, making it a PWA was almost free:
- Angular's PWA schematic adds a service worker and a manifest.
- The app assets and routes are cached for offline use.
On each device:
- I open the URL in Safari/Chrome.
- Use **'Add to Home Screen'** to install it.
- From then on, it behaves like a native app and works offline.
Data lives in the browser’s `localStorage` per device. Synchronization is intentionally manual (and simple):
1. On device A (e.g. Mac), I hit `Export data` and store the JSON file.
2. I transfer that file to device B (e.g. iPad) via AirDrop, iCloud Drive, or any other channel.
3. On device B I use `Import data` and pick that JSON file.
The import overwrites the local state after a confirmation dialog, so it works like a one-way sync from the device I treat as the 'source of truth'.
### My Personal Workflow
Here's how I actually use the app day-to-day:
1. **Collect problems & notes**
- Take screenshots of problem statements, code, or diagrams on the Mac.
- Create cards in the 'algo expert' deck, attaching screenshots to the back side and sometimes a short text summary to the front.
2. **Rate difficulties as I go**
- When I review on the iPad, I always rate how hard each card felt.
- Over time, easy cards drift towards 1–3, hard ones towards 8–10.
3. **Targeted sessions**
- Before an interview round, I might run:
- a `difficulty 7` session to hit tough but solvable questions, or
- an `Unsorted` session to quickly categorize new material.
4. **Occasional backup**
- Every once in a while I export a backup from my Mac and import it on the iPad.

This workflow gives me a sense of progress that's more tangible than a generic spaced-repetition schedule: I can see which difficulties are growing, and I can decide what to train based on how I feel that day.
### Takeaways
- You don’t always need a massive spaced-repetition engine. For some workflows, **manual difficulty control** plus filtering is enough—and actually more intuitive.
- A tiny domain model (`Deck`, `Flashcard`, `CardSideContent`, `DifficultyLevel`) is powerful when combined with a good UI.
- PWAs + GitHub Pages are underrated for personal tools: I get a cross-platform app with offline support without touching any backend.
- Multiple screenshots per card side turned out to be crucial for studying algorithms and code; the UI now treats images as first-class citizens, not just a decoration.
Most importantly, this app is small and *mine*: I understand every part of it, can tweak it whenever I feel like it, and it fits perfectly into how I learn.
